content.description: <math alttext="B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn varieties are genetically modified to produce a toxin that specifically kills corn borers, a type of insect that eats and damages corn crops. Insects that are not closely related to corn borers are not affected by the toxin. Figure 1 shows the increasing production of <math alttext="B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn varieties and the change in the use of broad-spectrum pesticides that were the primary means of killing corn borers before the invention of <math alttext="B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn.
content.question: Figure 1. Relative use of pesticides on corn fields and percent of <math alttext="B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn in crops How do the data in Figure 1 support the alternative hypothesis that increased use of <math alttext="B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn reduces the impact of corn farming on the natural environment?

choices.label: The increased use of <math alttext="B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn will result in rapid mutation in corn borers.
The toxin in <math alttext="B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn kills only the corn pests, leaving other insects unharmed.
Other insect species will replace corn borers and require additional applications of insecticides.

Since <math alttext="B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn is not natural like non-<math alttext="B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn, it will not interact with the rest of the environment.

content.answer: The toxin in <math alttext="B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn kills only the corn pests, leaving other insects unharmed.

skill.text: 5.D: Use data to evaluate a hypothesis or prediction, including rejecting or failing to reject the null hypothesis.
